;唐纳德·特朗普赢得总统职位一周后，我坐在我租住的房子里的折叠椅上华盛顿特区，准备剃掉我心爱的一头头发。第二天早上，我前往参加由白人民族主义者理查德·斯宾塞主持的集会，在那里我拍摄了一些镜头，这些镜头最终成为我的处女作电影《白噪音》的一部分，我认为淡化我的犹太外表是明智之举。我的室友打开了他的电动剃须刀。我犹豫是否参加集会。感觉有些不对劲。我需要建议——不是来自我的编辑，而是来自我的祖母尼娜。 “不要这样做，”她说，而我则滔滔不绝地讲述了这篇报道的重要性。 “但是，如果你这样做了，要小心。给我打电话。”

;

;我是在大屠杀幸存者身边长大的。作为十九世纪九十年代末和两千世纪初纽约郊区的一个孩子，我知道我的许多亲戚和家人朋友都经历过种族灭绝，留下了令人心碎的回忆。这些故事在我们的社区是如此普遍，以至于作为一个孩子，我们可以对它们不屑一顾。我和我的朋友们感到一种模糊的义务，那就是在我们的文化几乎完全被摧毁后保持其活力，但我们更专注于体育、学校或女孩，以给予这些历史应有的关注和尊重。有时，当幸存者将电视带入我们希伯来学校的课堂，向我们播放有关奥斯维辛的节目时，我们会抗议说我们想看《宋飞传》。

;我的祖母七岁了，还活着当希特勒入侵并引发第二次世界大战时，在波兰。在我的成长过程中，祖母对她的经历保持沉默。她很坚强，但很有趣。她从不浪费一丝食物。尽管在战争期间被迫中断了正规教育，但她拥有令人难以置信的知识。她是我生命中的一块磐石，是道德清晰的代言人。我感觉到让她如此特别的特质是她历史的产物，但我没有探究。我从来没有问过她在波兰发生了什么。没有人这样做。

;

;随着年龄的增长，我的社交圈里有越来越多的非犹太朋友和女朋友。我发现我认为理所当然的存在是罕见的：在我的成年生活中，大多数人从未见过幸存者。许多人甚至不知道六百万犹太人在大屠杀期间被杀害。我很震惊地发现，我一个亲近的人的亲戚暗中持有新纳粹观点，并在空闲时间学习《我的奋斗》。我在他家里找到了这本书，页边空白处写满了关于如何处理犹太人问题的笔记。

;

;所以我再次打电话给我的祖母，这次要求拍一部关于她生活的电影。 “这里没有故事，”她说。我告诉她，我希望我的孩子和孙子们了解她的历史，反犹太主义再次抬头，我身边的一个人也被她几十年前所面临的同样的罪恶所诱惑。一个真实的、活着的幸存者的证词可能是一剂强有力的解药。 “我们是一个正在消失的品种，”她软化了态度。 “所以，如果你想这么做，最好快点。”

;

;2022 年 7 月，我和一个小型摄制组搬进了她在长岛的房子，开始制作《妮娜与妮娜》。伊雷娜”讲述了我的祖母如何在大屠杀中幸存下来。自从十多年前我祖父去世后，她就独自生活，每天在社区中心打桥牌，练习瑜伽，并在后院喂鸟。这里有她逃离欧洲生活的痕迹，但你必须仔细观察。在她的钢琴上，在她的孩子、孙子和曾孙的图像之间，有一张她八十年前失踪的姐姐伊雷娜的小剪贴照片。为什么我没有问过她那是谁？

;
;
;

;当我们开始拍摄时，尼娜坐在她的黄色椅子上，她的白发刚刚打理过，喝了最后一口她的冰咖啡。 “大家好，女士们先生们，”当灯光照射在她那张苍老的脸上时，她说道。我们开始了长达几天的谈话：关于她在波兰的同化成长经历（“我从未见过棚屋”）；带着假证件躲在华沙隔都对面，看到街上的尸体（“我不知道谁最终捡起了尸体”）；她的妹妹和大约二十五名家庭成员（或用她的话来说是“每个人”）失踪了；以及她父亲反复讲出摆脱死亡之道的超凡魅力（“他的肆无忌惮;”）。船员们都哭了。作为一名纪录片导演，我知道要推动拍摄对象表达他们的情感——他们的愤怒或眼泪有助于让故事打动观众。但当我把祖母推向那个方向时，她会责骂我。她仍然保持坚忍。这不是一个受害者的故事。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;“正是因为没有眼泪，才赋予了它如此非凡的辛酸”，;埃罗尔·莫里斯;，传奇电影制片人，看完后给我写信。莫里斯直接面对镜头的表情和不敬的态度多年来一直激励着我的工作，尤其塑造了这部电影。莫里斯采访了约翰·勒卡雷、唐纳德·拉姆斯菲尔德、还有罗伯特·麦克纳马拉——他对我祖母总是爱不释手。 “她太他妈不可思议了，”他打电话给我说。他后来补充道，“这是我在电影中见过的最非凡的角色之一。”

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;

;最近，在九十一岁时，我的祖母乘飞机从纽约飞往加利福尼亚州，在宽容博物馆 (Museum of Tolerance) 展示她的故事，该博物馆是在大屠杀幸存者消失之前，我们一起开始了教育之旅。这场对话的背后是紧张气氛：自大屠杀以来对犹太人最致命的袭击，以及对加沙巴勒斯坦人的严厉打击。那天晚上，尼娜的人文主义表现得淋漓尽致，就像电影中一样。

;
;
;

;“我们都是生来可爱的孩子， “ 她问。 “会发生什么？”

;

;战争快结束时，尼娜看到捷克平民活活烧死了一名德国人。我认为肇事者罪有应得。毕竟，纳粹杀害了她的四位祖父母，以及几乎所有的阿姨、叔叔和表弟。我奶奶阻止了我。报复从来都是不对的。 “你不能对其他人这样做，”她说，对她最小的孙子抱有更好的期望。 “;来吧;。”

;

;大屠杀近八十年后，犹太人的生活再次感到不确定。当我的祖母去世后，我不知道该打电话给谁来了解这个世界。但我们还有在一起的时间，我最好不要沉默地坐着浪费时间。 “你应该经常来看我，”她握着我的手说道。 “不仅仅是电影。”

;在《王冠》第六季即最后一季中，Peter Morgan该剧的编剧兼创作者回到了他开始的地方。这个开头并不是摩根;史诗般的皇家编年史;的第一季，该剧于 2016 年 11 月发布，并以然后是 1947 年伊丽莎白公主与菲利普亲王的婚礼。《王冠》的起源可以追溯到十年前的 2006 年，电影《;《女王》;，由摩根编剧、史蒂芬·弗雷尔斯执导，海伦·米伦饰演君主，故事发生在威尔士王妃戴安娜去世后不久，1997 年 8 月下旬在巴黎逗留期间发生车祸。前所未有的公众哀悼。鲜花贡品密密麻麻地堆放在宫殿大门旁，玻璃纸和腐烂的花瓣形成了一条护城河。男人和女人在广场上公开哭泣。与此同时，女王和她的直系亲属在苏格兰的巴尔莫勒尔堡保持着一定的距离，他们在今年夏天早些时候搬到了这里，享受传统的假期，在经常出现的恶劣的高地天气中散步、跟踪、射击和野餐。当时，公众对女王缺乏公开表现的失望演变成了敌意，甚至愤怒：“向我们展示你的关心！” 《每日快报》通常是可靠的君主主义小报，其标题是这样咆哮。最终，女王迫于压力，要求她和家人从苏格兰返回伦敦。她也走在花束和拥挤的人群中，并在戴安娜去世一周后向全国发表电视特别讲话——这是她在位期间的第二次，第一次是在第一次海湾战争开始时。她的信息即使不是完全充满同理心，也向戴安娜致敬，称其为一位母亲和“一个让很多很多人快乐的人。”

;

;摩根在 2006 年的创新是从以下角度讲述这个故事：女王本人的观点——或者至少是她想象的观点，实际的女王并没有对事件做出自己的描述。迈克尔·辛 (Michael Sheen) 饰演的富有创新精神的新工党首相托尼·布莱尔 (Tony Blair) 则提供了一个对立面，布莱尔在影片中充当了女王的桥梁，让人们了解戴安娜在生前和死后如何被视为“人民的王妃”（布莱尔自己的说法）。恰当的短语。摩根以真正的女王当时未能表现出的同理心对待他版本的女王。这部电影展示了多么明显的无情——例如，最初未能在白金汉宫上空降半旗——实际上是对礼仪的遵守，女王一开始是不可想象的。戴安娜不再是殿下，而是普通公民。皇室如何看待前任女王——更不用说哀悼她了，这还没有先例。在《女王》中，摩根戏剧化地描述了君主立宪制国家（如英国）中君主的地位如何仅作为协议和先例的精心组合而存在：如果废除该框架，整个结构可能会崩溃。影片的开场场景显示伊丽莎白二世与一位为她画肖像的艺术家讨论即将到来的大选，这提醒观众君主不投票，名义上是由她或他的政府选举产生的。君主不可能是普通公民，就像在巴黎一样，路易·卡佩被斩首的鬼魂可能会提醒我们。

;

;在新一季的《王冠》中，摩根改变了视角。 1997 年 8 月发生的事件不再主要通过女王的视角来看待。相反，他把不可抗拒的戴安娜放在了突出的位置，因为她在生命的最后几周里经历了一场危险的炼金术：从未来的女王转变为一个特别稀有的普通公民的新形象。她先是与儿子威廉和哈里一起在富豪的游乐场圣特罗佩度假，然后乘坐穆罕默德·阿尔法耶德拥有的游艇度假，穆罕默德·阿尔法耶德出生于埃及，是哈洛德百货公司和巴黎丽兹酒店的所有者。波光粼粼的大海、灿烂的阳光、豪华的船只、尖叫的水战，与巴尔莫勒尔堡寒冷的环境形成了鲜明的对比，那里的荒野、粗花呢的践踏石南地和屠杀动物群的例行公事。而伊丽莎白·德比茨基 (Elizabeth Debicki) 饰演的戴安娜本人则异常真实，在经历了前几季的严峻痛苦之后，她终于在自己的皮肤中感到舒服了——正如各种优雅的泳衣所揭示的那样，她的皮肤同样光荣、统一、昂贵。金色的皇冠出现在节目的标题序列中。

;
;
;
;
;
;

;即使摩根试图在 2006 年关注戴安娜，也是不可能的。正如米伦当时在接受采访时所说，“这在英国是一个烫手山芋——如果不受到最严格的审查，你就无法接近这个话题。”戴安娜是最炙手可热的土豆。但时代变了，块茎已经冷却，这意味着摩根可以从不同的方向进行第二次研究。在《王冠》第一季开始时的;采访中摩根在与迈克尔·舒尔曼合作的这本杂志中指出，女王本人并不是最容易制作动画的角色。 “她不是一个作家的自然选择，因为她是一个智力和想象力有限的单音节女性，”他说，他肯定意识到，通过承担整个项目，他已经放弃了最终成为骑士的希望，因此可以自由地坦诚地说，或者甚至如他所愿的那样粗鲁无礼。摩根继续说道，“作为一名作家，我自然希望她成为托尼·女高音那样的人物，情绪多变且反复无常。”

;摩根的托尼·索普拉诺终于出现了在;第四季;中，以戴安娜·斯宾塞女士的形式出现——这位处女般的蓝血统，比查尔斯王子小十二岁，但成为威尔士王妃的命运却落到了他的身上。从一开始，《王冠》就毫不犹豫地描绘了戴安娜的反复无常。在第四季初期，艾玛·科林 (Emma Corrin) 饰演的刚刚订婚的迪夫人在宫廷冰箱里暴饮暴食，然后逃进浴室，干呕到皇家厕所里。 《王冠》中的饮食失调事件引起了争议，而且其生动性足以引起触发警告。但他们没有透露出公主本人不愿意揭露的一切。 1995 年，在接受 BBC 采访时，当被直接问到她与贪食症的斗争时，她回答说，她已经患有这种疾病好几年了。 “这是你给自己造成的，因为你的自尊心处于低潮，你认为自己没有价值或有价值，”她说。

;
;
;

;该剧;第五季< /a>;，现在由德比基扮演的戴安娜的肖像变得更加复杂。摩根的描述表明，戴安娜对她私人心理健康斗争的披露是作为另一场斗争的战略举措——一场争夺对她分居的丈夫查尔斯和更大的王室的公共关系优势的斗争。在第五季中，摩根搬上银幕的戴安娜非常有魅力，而且非常像她的原版。 （与戴安娜关系密切的资深王室记者理查德·凯 (Richard Kay) 在《每日邮报》中写道，德比基“拥有戴安娜王妃天生的优雅、顽皮和美丽。她既有自己的举止，也有她的声音。确实如此。” ，闭上眼睛，我发现自己想象那是我的朋友戴安娜在说话。”）但第五季的戴安娜也很善于操纵，沉迷于关注和戏剧性，而这对她来说曾经是非常不受欢迎的。由记者马丁·巴希尔（Martin Bashir）主持的英国广播公司（BBC）著名采访——戴安娜在采访中表达了对查尔斯和他当时的情妇、现在的卡米拉王后“我们三个人”的控诉——;后来透露;，通过令人震惊的双重手段获得。 《王冠》描绘了巴希尔的口是心非；但这也表明戴安娜不仅仅是巴希尔的受害者。她正在使用她所掌握的最强大的工具来对抗这片土地上最有权势的家族。

;
;
;

; ;第五季的一些评论家;认为，在将戴安娜描绘成出于报复心理，摩根决定将自己的命运投向当权派，将现在的国王查理三世描绘成一个陷入困境的人，并展示了戴安娜在这种不可能的情况下的表现。然而，在第六季中，银幕上的戴安娜再次进化。新一季的前四集，包括戴安娜的去世，展现了她的悲伤、知情、遗憾、甚至宽容。当多米尼克·韦斯特饰演的查尔斯从戴安娜的监护下接走威廉和哈里时，我们知道这将是最后一次，他深情地问道：“尽管我们在结婚方面并不出色，但我们能在……方面表现出色吗？” 。 。所有这些？” “我想是的，”戴安娜眼睛湿润，但充满感情。她悲伤地补充道，“她没能留住她梦想中的男人，而是她梦想中的朋友。”这仍然不完全是天作之合——两个阵营在小报上继续交战——但这表明最终可能会出现更融洽的和解。

;当然不是。就像《女王》中君主在山腰上独自瞥见的一头雄鹿，当它被邻近庄园的付费客人射杀时，它会哀悼——或者就像在这一季的《王冠》中，威廉王子射杀的雄鹿死了，这是他第一次猎杀，身上沾满了——戴安娜的血，她以一位女猎人的名字命名，永远只能是狩猎的受害者。 《王冠》令人痛苦地描绘了她最后几周不断升级的疯狂。她不仅受到狗仔队的侵入性跟踪，还被那些她信任会照顾她的人背叛了。另一位表面上的朋友穆罕默德·阿尔法耶德 (Mohamed Al-Fayed) 让她陷入了自己的王朝戏剧中：他通过无能的长子多迪·法耶德 (Dodi Fayed) 与未来国王的母亲之间的婚姻联盟来追求英国的合法性。

;At the eleventh hour on the eleventh day of the eleventh month, a hundred and five years after the guns fell silent on the Western Front, a crowd assembled next to the Cenotaph, Britain's monument to its war dead, squinted, shuffled, raised phones into the low November sunlight, and waited for somebody to ruin the moment. Since the Hamas attack on October 7th, there had been four consecutive Saturdays of protests in central London, to oppose Israel's retaliation in Gaza. The fifth march, coinciding with Armistice Day—the anniversary of the end of the First World War—was seen by the British establishment as one too many. ;Rishi Sunak;, the Prime Minister, said that it would be disrespectful. The Metropolitan Police asked the protest's organizers to cancel it. But most people could also see that it was wrong, on almost every conceivable level, to try to shut down a large-scale peace march on the day when the country gathers itself to reflect on the waste and horror of war. Suella Braverman, who would soon be fired as Britain's Home Secretary, either did not see this, or could see it very plainly, and chose to inflame the situation anyway. Braverman, the current idol of the right wing of the Conservative Party, has described the pro-Palestinian demonstrations as “hate marches.” On November 8th, she published an op-ed in the ;Times; of London saying that the police “play favourites” with left-wing and anti-Israel protesters, as opposed to their firm handling of nationalists and soccer hooligans. It was a stunt, designed to provoke everybody all at once. On the eve of Armistice Day, a spokesperson for Sunak observed crisply that Braverman's article had not been approved by the Prime Minister—“and we are looking into that.”

;

;On Saturday, I reached the gates of Downing Street, within sight of the Cenotaph, at 10:30 ;AM;, as a group of around a hundred far-right nationalists were scuffling with police. They were mostly white men, wearing jeans, tweed caps, Fred Perry jackets, and other subtle emblems of London's more violent soccer fan clubs: Chelsea, West Ham, Millwall FC There were soccer chants—“England till I die”—and Union Jacks draped over shoulders. “You get your truncheons out,” they sang at the police. Many masked their faces. Not far away, the pipes and drums of the London Scottish regiment sounded, ahead of the brief military ceremony—and two minutes of silence—to mark the Armistice at eleven o'clock.

;

;The energy in the crowd centered on Tommy Robinson, a founder of the ;English Defence League;, an extremist Islamophobic organization that formally disbanded in 2015. Robinson, a compact, aggressive presence, whose given name is Stephen Christopher Yaxley-Lennon, is said to be exploring a comeback. He was wearing a green body warmer under a maroon jacket with plastic goggles set into the hood. Even though the pro-Palestinian march was gathering more than two miles away, and the police were enforcing an “exclusion zone” to keep protesters away from the Armistice Day events, and the place was crawling with soldiers, Robinson and his supporters had shown up, in their words, to defend the Cenotaph. “You see how they've just treated our people coming in to pay their respects?” Robinson said, showing me a video on his phone of the violence from a few moments earlier. “There's no opposition here,” he said, sounding a touch disappointed, “so why wouldn't you just let us in?”

;

;The reaction of Britain's leading politicians to Israel's war with Hamas has been terse and pedestrian; they are apparently unwilling to acknowledge the full tragedy of the violence or the political imagination that will be required to end it. Sunak doesn't seem terribly interested in diplomacy and has stayed strictly within the shadow of the US policy response to the crisis and the instinctive sentiment of the Conservative Party, which has become increasingly pro-Israeli since Brexit. (Trade between the UK and Israel was worth seven billion pounds in 2022.) ;Keir Starmer;, the leader of the Labour Party, has a powerful reason for never wanting to talk about Israel or Palestine, and that reason is ;Jeremy Corbyn;, his predecessor, whose leadership was dogged by allegations of antisemitism. Last month, it took Starmer nine days to modify his apparent support for the cutting of power and water supplies to Gaza, and his reluctance to criticize Israel's prosecution of the war has led to the resignation of around fifty Party officials so far. On November 6th, John Casson, a former foreign-policy adviser to ;David Cameron;, the country's Prime Minister between 2010 and 2016, told the BBC that the shallowness of the political debate in the UK reminded him of the prelude to the invasion of Iraq in 2003. “So far, what we've got is a posture. 'Stand with Israel' is a posture—it's not a policy,” Casson said. “Given the chilling loss of civilian life—thousands of innocent lives every week—we have a responsibility to set out a description of the exit from the cycle of violence.”

;

;In the vacuum, other voices have found purchase. In the early weeks of the war, Humza Yousaf, the First Minister of Scotland, whose in-laws were trapped in Gaza, was a rare national voice of realism and despair. Last week, Yousaf, who has been reunited with his wife's closest family members, described himself as “beyond angry” at Braverman's rhetoric. “If Armistice was about anything, my goodness, it's about peace,” Yousaf told reporters in Dundee. Elsewhere, bad actors have thrived. On November 7th, the Community Security Trust, an organization that has monitored antisemitism in the UK since 1984, recorded its worst thirty-two-day period on record: a total of more than eleven hundred incidents, including twenty-four cases of children being abused on their way to or from school. The entrance to the Wiener Holocaust Library, Britain's foremost Holocaust archive, had “Gaza” scrawled on it in red paint. Online, the Palestinian flag and the poppy, the symbol of remembrance for Britain's war dead, were juxtaposed. Videos circulated of Muslims praying in the streets of Westminster and volunteers, selling poppies to raise money for veterans, caught up in pro-Palestinian sit-ins in railway stations. A fake audio recording went around of Sadiq Khan, the mayor of London, who is Muslim, seeming to suggest that Armistice Day, rather than the protest, should be rescheduled. “You have a police force who work for Sadiq Khan whose job it is to oppress the English people,” Robinson told me, by the Cenotaph. “And people have had enough. That's what you're seeing today.”

;

;The first Armistice commemoration took place on November 11, 1919. King George V requested two minutes of silence: one for all who went to fight and who had come home, and one for those who did not return. “All work, all sound, and all locomotion should cease,” the King wrote. Factories came to a stop. Prisoners stood in their cells. “The hush was complete; it was eerie; it was silent prayer and a thanksgiving,” the ;Pall Mall Gazette; reported. When the first “great silence” ended, an ex-serviceman stepped forward and buttonholed William Kay, the Lord Mayor of Manchester, on the steps of the Town Hall. “May I state the case for the living as well as the dead,” he asked, according to the Manchester ;Evening News;. “Not here. This is not the place or time,” came the reply. In the twenties and thirties, the Armistice became a frequent occasion for antiwar protests, by war widows, pacifists, and veterans who felt that the day's rituals had become too martial and celebratory. On the evening of November 4, 1934, three hundred women stood under umbrellas in the rain in Trafalgar Square, many wearing white-poppy rosettes—for peace—after their request to stage a protest on Armistice Day was denied. They struggled to be heard. “The authorities have also refused to turn off the fountains in the Square and let us have loud speakers,” Mary Millar, of the London Co-operative Women's Guild, complained.

;
;
;

;On Saturday, inside the exclusion zone, the bugles and the silence were immaculate. Even a hovering police helicopter drifted away. You could hear the sound of every falling leaf. I fell into step with Lewis, a former private in the Parachute Regiment, who served in Afghanistan and was carrying two beers in the sunshine. “It went much better than I thought it would,” Lewis said. Next to him, his friend was speaking loudly into his phone: “Makes me proud to be fucking English, you know?” Lewis thought it was a shame that Armistice Day and the pro-Palestinian march had to be separated and so heavily policed. “The poppy is there for everyone, but, personally, it doesn't feel that it is,” he said. “There is so much protest and conflict in this country alone, with the people who live here, you can't really portray such a . 。 。 I don't know the word . 。 。 such an innocence?” While he was speaking, a car cut across Parliament Square with Palestinian flags flying out its windows. “Fucking knobhead!” Lewis's friend yelled. “It seems to me you have to be one way or the other,” Lewis said, “and the town has been blocked off in that way.”

;

;I walked along the banks of the Thames to meet the peace march. Between the two public events, Londoners did ordinary Saturday things: jogging, kayaking on the river, playing in the park. A sticker on a road sign on Lambeth Bridge showed Iván Illarramendi, a forty-six-year-old Spanish Israeli, who was thought to have been taken hostage by Hamas from Kibbutz Kissufim, which is about a mile from the Gaza Strip, on what was supposed to be another normal Saturday. Illarramendi and his wife, Dafna, a Chilean national, were later found to have died in the initial attack on the kibbutz, which killed fifteen others, including eight migrant workers from Thailand. On Vauxhall Bridge, by the route of the protest, the Communist Party of Great Britain was handing out literature describing Zionism as a “racist, antisemitic and reactionary tool of imperialism.” A volunteer was explaining how the Nazis had supported Zionism. “Truth is truth,” he said, shrugging. Against the walls of the headquarters of Britain's Secret Intelligence Service, the police were detaining a group of white men, one of whom was wearing an England soccer jersey under his yellow hoodie. The police arrested at least a hundred and twenty-six people at the protests on Saturday, the majority of whom were right-wing men, looking for a fight. “I think it's helmets-on time,” I heard an officer say, jogging to join a barricade of vehicles and riot police, blocking in a beered-up crowd outside a pub close to Tate Britain.

;

;The pro-Palestine protest was a tide that asked you to step aside. An estimated three hundred thousand people marched from Park Lane to the US Embassy, on the south side of the Thames. The silence was gone. It was all sound and locomotion: flags and flares, pigeons startled by the constant drone of two circling helicopters, and placards and chants, made up of the contested language and imagery of the conflict: “Exist, resist, return”; “Humanity vs. 'Israel' ”; pictures of watermelons. The chorus of “Palestine will be free” was answered, not always, but often, by “From the river to the sea.” I saw a small cardboard sign that read “Hamas Are Terrorists, Free the Hostages.” Its bearer was deep in conversation, and that was in line with the amicable, almost positive atmosphere of the protest. When a posse of masked men emerged from a side street, looking for a scrap, volunteers hustled the march to the other side of the road. “Just stick with me,” a protester, who didn't want to give his name, said to his young son, as they crossed Vauxhall Bridge in the sunshine, and flares went off behind them. The man's wife, a British Muslim, described learning about Armistice Day in school. “ 'Armistice' means 'ceasefire.' That's what we are asking for. People don't actually understand,” she said. “It's like the same thing they are repeating,” her husband replied. “It's again a genocide.”

;

;As the light failed, splinter groups of all kinds had run-ins with the police. A group of a hundred and fifty pro-Palestinian demonstrators was detained for aiming fireworks at officers. On the banks of the Thames, someone filmed a few dozen men chanting, “Who the fuck is Allah?” The following afternoon, Braverman gave her verdict, on X, formerly known as Twitter. While the Home Secretary mentioned “counter protesters,” she was mainly concerned with the chanting and placards at the peace march. “This can't go on. Week by week, the streets of London are being polluted by hate, violence, and antisemitism,” she wrote. “Further action is necessary.”

;These were her last public comments as Home Secretary. On Monday morning, Sunak removed Braverman from her post and replaced her with James Cleverly, the Foreign Secretary, who until then had been leading Britain's diplomatic efforts in the Middle East. He was replaced—to actual gasps from reporters in Downing Street—by David Cameron, who became the first former Prime Minister to return to the Cabinet in half a century. Cameron has not been a Member of Parliament since he resigned after calling, and losing, the Brexit referendum in 2016. King Charles promptly made him a baron, so that he could take up the job.

;

;Appointing Cameron is Sunak's most flamboyant decision since taking office. It swept Braverman and her antics, which Sunak tolerated and endorsed for more than a year, off the news cycle, but whether it will lead to any meaningful change in Britain's policy toward Israel and Palestine is doubtful. Cameron's international adventures as Prime Minister—a naïve wooing of China, a bungled military intervention in Libya, and a failed renegotiation of Britain's role in the European Union—weren't much to write home about. He has become the country's seventh Foreign Secretary in as many years, which tells you something about the political chaos that his government bequeathed to its successors. Quite how Cameron and his patrician air and association with mistakes of the past fit into Sunak's political program, ahead of a general election next year, is anybody's guess. It doesn't feel like much of a plan. More of a posture. ♦

;;Donald Trump; talks a lot of trash, of course. But three days after his campaign appearance in Claremont, New Hampshire, on Saturday, some of the words he used are still reverberating. At the end of a long and rambling speech, Trump said the following: “In honor of our great veterans on Veterans Day, we pledge to you that we will root out the communists, Marxists, fascists, and the radical-left thugs that live like vermin within the confines of our country—that lie and steal and cheat on elections, and will do anything possible; they'll do anything, whether legally or illegally, to destroy America, and to destroy the American Dream.”

;

;If the phrase “live like vermin within the confines of our country” sounds vaguely familiar, it should. In February, 1933, days after Adolf Hitler was appointed as Chancellor of Germany, Wilhelm Kube, a Nazi politician, wrote in a propaganda publication, as reported at the time by the ;;Jewish Daily Bulletin;;: “The Jews, like vermin, form a line from Potsdamerplatz until Anhalter Banhof. 。 。 .The only way to smoke out the vermin is to expel them.” In 1936, when Oswald Mosley's British Fascists were harassing Jews in London's East End, they referred to them as “rats and vermin from the gutters of Whitechapel.” Hitler himself used similar language more than once. In a 1934 interview, he said, “If I can send the flower of the German nation into the hell of war without the smallest pity, then surely I have the right to remove millions of an inferior race that breeds like vermin!”

;

;To be sure, Trump wasn't targeting Jewish people during his speech in New Hampshire. Although he sometimes peddles antisemitic tropes, such as running a campaign ad attacking “global special interests” that featured pictures of George Soros and Lloyd Blankfein, he has also made determined efforts to wean Jewish voters from their historical affiliation with the Democratic Party. But that hardly excuses his language or diminishes its significance. As he leads the 2024 Presidential polls nearly a year out from Election Day, he's taking the sort of hateful rhetoric that in the past he's used about immigrants and minorities and applying it to his political enemies and legal antagonists.

;

;This shift largely reflects the embattled position that Trump finds himself in, as he faces criminal indictments in four different courts—and his eagerness to save his own skin, regardless of the costs to American democracy. Just as the Fascists' hateful rhetoric during the interwar period was intended to dehumanize, delegitimize, and intimidate its targets, Trump is trying to do the same thing to the individuals and institutions on his enemies list, which seems to include anybody who won't forgive his attempt to overturn the 2020 election results or who supports the subsequent efforts to hold him to account. The foes he is targeting appear to include ;President Joe Biden;, congressional Democrats, Never Trump Republicans, the Justice Department, the courts, senior military officers, and the media—ie, many of the central institutions of American democracy.

;
;
;

;Until 2020, Trump reserved his most offensive language for undocumented immigrants. During the 2016 campaign, he referred to them as “drug dealers,” “criminals,” “rapists.” From the Oval Office, he referred to them as “animals,” and in a 2018 tweet he said that Democrats wanted them “to pour into and infest our country, like MS-13.” This dehumanizing rhetoric went down well with many of Trump's hard-core supporters. He also made derogatory comments about prominent Black figures, calling Representative Maxine Waters “low IQ” and Don Lemon, the former CNN anchor, “dumb.” He referred to Baltimore, a predominantly Black city, as a “disgusting, rat- and rodent-infested mess.”

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;After Trump got criminally indicted earlier this year, he pivoted to his new targets. In June, hours after pleading not guilty to federal charges of mishandling classified documents and conspiring to obstruct justice, he claimed that President Biden “together with a band of his closest thugs, misfits, and Marxists, tried to destroy American democracy.” He added, “If the communists get away with this, it won't stop with me.” Since then, Trump has routinely adopted this sort of language, occasionally adding the term “fascists” to his repertoire, perhaps as an effort to muddle the meaning of the word. At a speech in Miami earlier this month, on the eve of the off-year election, he urged the crowd to “crush the communists at the ballot box.”

;

;Describing his political opponents as “vermin” on Veterans Day represented a further escalation, and there is no reason to believe that he was unaware of the history he was invoking. (He also posted the same language to his social-media account, and it hasn't been taken down.) Still, Trump's incendiary comments were part of a whole that includes him accusing the ;retired general Mark Milley; of treason and suggesting that he should be executed; repeatedly referring to Special Counsel Jack Smith as “deranged” and a “thug”; and constantly lobbing charges of political bias at Judge Arthur F. Engoron, who is presiding over Trump's New York civil trial, and Judge Tanya S. Chutkan, who is overseeing ;the January 6th case; in Washington, DC

During his speech in New Hampshire, Trump blatantly flouted this order. He again referred to Smith as “deranged” and a “Trump-hating prosecutor,” and he went on: “his wife and family despise me much more than he does.” It remains to be seen if Chutkan will take any additional action against Trump. But, whatever happens, Trump's rhetoric is only further raising the stakes for the 2024 election.

;

;All Presidential contests are important, of course. But this one is shaping up as a struggle for the future of the country—a struggle in which one of the major political parties is under the control of a would-be strongman, who, during his Veterans Day speech, also took the opportunity to praise the governing styles of Xi Jinping and Viktor Orbán. It's a struggle in which the former President's associates are reportedly busy preparing post-election plans to staff the Justice Department with Trump loyalists who are willing to target his opponents; to invoke the Insurrection Act and dispatch the military to political demonstrations; and to build giant camps to hold undocumented migrants. In other words, it's a struggle to prevent the election of a President whose embrace of fascistic imagery and authoritarian governance goes well beyond what comes out of his mouth. That, unfortunately, is where we are. The reality cannot be avoided. ♦

;Some of the main conflicts in ;Todd Haynes;'s new film, “May December” (which opens Friday), are practically shouted from behind the camera, and they drown out other ones on which the story equally depends. The movie is a loose adaptation of the real-life story of ;Mary Kay Letourneau; and Vili Fualaau, who met in the mid-nineties at middle school and began a sexual relationship.莱图诺是一名三十多岁的教师。富阿劳十二岁。莱图诺被判犯有强奸罪并入狱。他们育有两个女儿，女儿获释后，他们团聚并结婚。 In “May December,” the couple is Gracie Atherton (;Julianne Moore;) and Joe Yoo (Charles Melton).现在他已经三十多岁了，而她也已经五十多岁了。他们有三个孩子，住在佐治亚州萨凡纳。她是一名面包师，同时还教授插花课程。他是一名 X 射线技术员，但他真正的热情是帝王蝶，他精心饲养并放归野外。 Gracie has a grand and lordly manner, and the mild-mannered Joe gets the brunt of her lording: when he tends his specimens, she orders him to get his “bugs” out of the house before company arrives.

;

;The company arriving is Elizabeth Berry (;Natalie Portman;), a well-known TV actress, who's preparing to portray Gracie in a movie and wants to get to know the family.格雷西和乔迫切需要关怀和同情——作为当地的贱民，他们太习惯于看到一箱箱的粪便送到他们家了——他们热切地欢迎伊丽莎白。海恩斯很快就明确表示，格雷西和伊丽莎白都是自恋的操纵者——也许是电影中的天作之合，但很快就会扭曲观众的根基兴趣。 (Whom the viewer is rooting for—I'd say by design—is Joe, but Haynes keeps Joe as his hole card, indeterminate nearly throughout and then revealed with precise and narrow certainty.)

;

;Elizabeth is TV-famous—heads turn when she walks into the local high school and a restaurant—but not taken seriously as an actress, and she has a heap of ambition invested in the film.她告诉格雷西，她有一些东西需要证明，因为她来自一个学者家庭，他们认为她太聪明了，不适合当演员。 （格雷西的回归谦逊是无价的。）尽管伊丽莎白和格雷西一样以自我为中心，但滑稽的是，她不适合描绘她。当格雷西提到她的一个兄弟住在明尼阿波利斯并为双胞胎工作时，伊丽莎白想知道是哪对双胞胎，格雷西带着凯瑟琳·赫本那样的居高临下的态度，解释说这是“一支职业棒球队”。这位女演员对这个世界、格雷西或家庭并不真正感兴趣，只对她希望他们的故事能给她带来的成功感兴趣。 Unsurprisingly, her ethical judgment proves as dubious as her artistic intentions.

;

;The front-loading of the movie with such clear tensions leaves lots of cinematic space to fill, whether with information or mood, characterization or context.其效果是一种自我施加的导演挑战，即使海恩斯没有完全成功，他至少也做出了大胆的努力，充满了令人难忘的台词、图像、手势和语调。他巧妙地在选角中展现了格雷西和伊丽莎白的不匹配，更不用说他对演员的指导了。摩尔将她的戏剧性表达具体化，微妙但明确，而波特曼却无所事事地表达了很多：她的表演是在她的思想中，她越少推动，就越能表现出来。当波特曼的面具般的态度让伊丽莎白在会见并向镇上的人询问格雷西的情况时——包括格雷西的前夫（DW莫菲特饰）和她的前律师（劳伦斯阿兰西奥饰）——但格雷西一眼就看穿了伊丽莎白的饥饿空虚。在电影中最精彩的时刻之一，伊丽莎白拥抱了格雷西。 Gracie doesn't lift a hand in return.

;
;
;

;What's not out front (and what would be a cruel spoiler to divulge) is Elizabeth's gamesmanship involving Joe, her contemporary, whom she attempts to envision through Gracie's eyes.海恩斯根据萨米·伯奇的剧本，以一种冰冷的轻快感上演了最终的游戏，这与他不断变化的戏剧视角相匹配。这就是他随意而谨慎地选择的无所不知，结果有时感觉就像是一个确定性的木偶剧院，有弦乐在表演。有些逆转和启示更像是为了获得道德分数的决定，而不是叙事结果。海恩斯从一开始就明确表达了自己的观点——他严肃地斜视着伊丽莎白和格雷西，但仍然尽力给予他们一定程度的尊严和同情。 He's clearly on Team Joe, which gives him the dramatic problem that he doesn't seem to find the person to whom he's most sympathetic especially interesting.

;

;The clarity of these conflicts is achieved by some conspicuous omissions.首先，伊丽莎白和这对夫妇之间的关系没有定义。他们似乎已经同意让这位女演员进入他们家了，但是交易是什么呢？他们的人生故事有契约吗？他们有报酬吗？或者预期的回报只是一种富有同情心的描绘，一个积极的公众形象？这部电影也没有透露家族内部关于伊丽莎白和电影的谈判。这对夫妇的三个孩子也不可避免地与这位女演员有牵连。我们看到他们的反应，但这些反应没有明确的意义，因为孩子们同意什么，或者他们的父母强加给他们什么，仍然未知。 《五月十二月》的根本问题是好莱坞的做事方式；当有人要求拍摄你的人生故事时，它会提醒你跑多快。这部电影以讽刺为中心，伊丽莎白带着对她所认为的家庭真相的可疑追求，进入了这个家庭，并成为潜在反应的即时催化剂，一种活生生的真理血清，消极中的消极。 (The result, unfortunately, is a climactic scene, bringing decades of trouble to the surface, that's one of the most ludicrous “duh” moments in recent movies.)

;

;The film's sympathies are drawn as if with a ruler—only the boxes of shit are perhaps a bit much. It's as if Haynes were pulling a reverse Wolfie, making sure (exactly as ;Martin Scorsese; didn't do, in “;The Wolf of Wall Street;”) that his own stern judgments suffuse the drama throughout.考虑到阿瑟顿-柳家族的骇人听闻的背景故事，与斯科塞斯扮演的骗子的纯粹贪污罪孽相比，谁能责怪他呢？然而结果是海恩斯抓住了一个极其奇怪和令人不安的故事并将其呈现出来。 。 。正好。在传达它时，这部电影提供了优秀的演员、良好的对话、出色的表演、稳定的基调、一些令人难忘的转折、一些引人注目的时刻——这显然是一位大导演的作品——但它意味着它的意义，仅此而已。它不会留下很大的神秘感，也不会产生很大的歧义，因为海恩斯知道他每时每刻的立场，并希望确保观众也知道。他修剪掉所有松散的末端，以免有人拉扯其中的一个，使固定的视角瓦解。正如经常发生的那样，实质问题始于形式问题。这部电影的戏剧框架被紧紧地束缚和封闭，海恩斯并没有刺穿或破坏它，让故事所暗示的丰富细节——艺术和金钱、权力和傲慢——得以呈现。结果引人入胜、引起共鸣，但它仍然让人感觉不完整、未完成。 ♦

;加沙战争以及美国对乌克兰的持续支持，一些人担心，随着美国军备的耗尽，台湾可能会陷入危险的脆弱境地。 ;乔什·保罗;，美国国务院前政治军事事务主任表示，随着以色列军方对精确制导炸弹和导弹等产品提出竞争性需求，台湾对美国武器的供应可能会受到限制。 （他指出，在乌克兰，军队部署的先进武器较少。）保罗说，战争使美军自己的库存捉襟见肘，但是，由于领导人一直在节约供应，“我不认为五角大楼的弹药不足” ”。不过，这可能会改变。众议院最近通过了一项法案，将向以色列提供约 140 亿美元的军事援助，并由拜登总统酌情从美国库存中额外提供价值 2.5 亿美元的军备。该法案尚未获得参议院审议。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;两年前，当我开始报道;关于台湾的文章;，但我的请求被拒绝了。然后，今年十月，指挥官梅根·格林打电话说：“我们已经获得批准了。”她没有说为什么，但我推断这至少部分是由于拜登与习峰会的临近。中国军队的侵略性也越来越大。上个月，一架中国 J-11 战斗机在南海上空与一架美国 B-52 的距离不到 10 英尺。

;
;
;

;我飞往马尼拉，在那里登上了一架 MH -60直升机。这艘由两台涡轮轴发动机驱动的飞船降落在拉斐尔·佩拉尔塔号上，当时它仍在菲律宾以西的南中国海波涛汹涌的水域中航行。当我上船时，这艘船刚刚经过南沙群岛，这是一个有争议的群岛，中国已将至少三个环礁军事化。

;
;
;

;拉斐尔·佩拉尔塔 (Rafael Peralta) 以一名海军陆战队员的名字命名，他在伊拉克为救战友而投身手榴弹，不幸身亡。大多数水手睡在三层高的铺位上。走廊的宽度刚好可以通过，食物的味道就像是高中食堂的食物（有一天晚上的晚餐是玉米热狗），船被风无情地摇晃着。

;;;;

;船长库珀于 2022 年接管了拉斐尔·佩拉尔塔号。像我在船上遇到的许多水手一样，他在远离海洋的地方长大：在哥伦布郊外的俄亥俄州贝克斯利，他的父亲在那里工作股票经纪人和他的母亲在学校教书。他的父母希望把他推向更广阔的世界，坚持让他们的儿子离开俄亥俄州去上大学，库珀获得了国会任命，进入马里兰州安纳波利斯的美国海军学院。自从库珀接任拉斐尔·佩拉尔塔号的指挥以来，他和他的船员们已经连续在海上呆了几个月，只短暂停靠港口以获取补给和燃料。他告诉我，他几乎只喜欢看水：“这是海滨地产，每天二十个小时。”

;

;库珀，四十二岁，在桥上来来往往——高架隔间，上面堆满了无线电和雷达，几乎可以看到大海的全景。当他不在时，拉斐尔·佩拉尔塔由一群军官驾驶，其中大多数人只有二十多岁。其中一位是来自爱达荷州博伊西的二十一岁的法官梅梅里安少尉。和船上的大多数军官一样，梅默里安是移民的孩子，他的动机是为国家服务。她的母亲来自墨西哥，父亲来自叙利亚；她五月从海军学院毕业。 “我们感谢这个国家为我们家庭所做的一切，”她说。在南中国海，梅梅里安驾驶着“拉斐尔·佩拉尔塔”号加油，这是一项棘手的操作，要求她驾驶船只与一艘大型加油船“沃利·施艾拉”号并排行驶，而两艘船的航行速度都接近每小时 20 节。 （驱逐舰的油箱容量为四十五万加仑，可持续使用两个月。）

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Rafael Peralta 是一个可怕的存在：五百九英尺长，装备有大约九十六枚导弹。但据估计，中国海军的军舰数量比美国多 79 艘，而且如果发生台湾问题，中国拥有巨大的地理优势。在五角大楼和华盛顿智库举办的战争游戏中，美国通常会失败。

;

;无论哪一方获胜，中美之间的战争都将是灾难性的，不仅仅是从人类角度来看——一些估计死亡人数达到数十万人——但也有经济上的。台湾海峡是世界上最繁忙的航道之一，每年有近3万亿美元的货物经过；水道的任何破坏几乎肯定会严重影响全球经济。

;

;对于许多观察家来说，最令人担忧的可能性是海峡的偶然碰撞可能引发更广泛的战争。当拉斐尔·佩拉尔塔号接近海峡时，库珀接过舵，并在接下来的十二个小时里一直掌舵，希望避免麻烦。 6月，一艘中国军舰;直接穿过;美国海军“忠勋”号航道通过水道时的路径。在国际外交的生硬散文中，美国指责中国进行“不安全的海上互动”。美国和中国海军军官有时会进行激烈的无线电交流，中国人通常会告诉美国军舰离开。马里兰州罗克维尔的少尉 Young Kim 说：“有时它们会靠得非常近。”

;大约 8 ;下午，拉斐尔·佩拉尔塔号和渥太华号距离台湾南岸如此之近，以至于我的手机在公海上长期中断服务，突然响了起来。然后，当两艘船进入海峡时，他们遇到了模糊的灯光全景——数十艘渔船，以及一列货船和油轮。渔船在船头摆动，形成了一系列危险的障碍。

;

;拉斐尔·佩拉尔塔号和渥太华号开始在渔船中穿行，渔船在黑暗中几乎看不见。距离我们船头几英里的地方，两艘中国军舰似乎几乎完全停在水里，无法机动。他们开始慢慢地过去，但不到一个小时，拉斐尔·佩拉尔塔号就把他们抛在了后面。 “我们现在已经领先他们数英里了，”库珀说道。

;
;
;

;被中国船只跟踪后连续几天，“拉斐尔·佩拉尔塔”号和“渥太华”号几乎畅通无阻地穿过台湾海峡。天亮时，我们穿过台湾北端，进入东海。但即使是相对安静的通道也没有摆脱国际竞争。太阳升起时，美国海军发表声明称，“这次过境并不引人注目，没有挑衅性，符合国际法。”中国人民解放军回应称，它一直在监视这些船只，并辩称美国“炒作”过境是一种挑衅。库珀表示，在某种程度上，将冲突保留在言辞范围内是美国海军存在的全部目的。 “我希望的是，习近平每天醒来，看到我们出现在地平线上，他都会对自己说，‘今天不是这样的日子。’” ” ♦
